title: Astronomers reveals telescope photo of two stars being born in pretzel-like a swirl of dust
text:
A stunning image of two young stars being birthed amidst a pretzel-like swirl of interstellar dust and gas has been captured by telescopes in Chile.

The pair of baby stars are located in the so-called '[BHB2007] 11 system', the newest addition to a small star cluster in the Barnard 59 dark nebula.

A dark nebula is a cloud of interstellar gas so dense that it blocks out the light from any objects behind it. Barnard 59 is part of a larger cloud called the Pipe Nebula.

Previous studies of the binary star system had only revealed its broad outer structure, rather than its inner composition.

The findings help to shine light on how binary systems with similarly-sized stars form and grow from their surrounding disks of dust and gas.

A stunning image of two young stars being birthed amidst a pretzel-like swirl of interstellar dust and gas has been captured by telescopes in Chile

Astrochemist Felipe Alves of the Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics and colleagues imaged the star system in high resolution using the so-called Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) in Chile.

ALMA is an array of 66 radio telescopes designed to shine a light on both the universe's era of star formation by looking at far away objects and to provide detailed images of local star and planet formation.

'We see two compact sources that we interpret as circumstellar disks around the two young stars,' said Dr Alves.

'The size of each of these disks is similar to the asteroid belt in our Solar System and the separation between them is 28 times the distance between the Sun and the Earth.'

Circumstellar disks are rings of dust and gas that surround young stars. As material from the rings fall into the stars, they grow bigger.

Surrounding the two small disks, the researchers found a larger disk — one with a complex, pretzel-like structure of loops — with a total mass equivalent to 80 times that of our neighbourhood gas giant, Jupiter.

The researchers believe that the baby stars gather material from the bigger, pretzel-shaped disk in two stages.

Firstly, twirling loops of flowing dust and gas are transferred to the smaller, individual discs, as seen the in image taken by ALMA. From here, the matter is passed on into the respective star.

Previous studies of the binary star system had only revealed its broad outer structure, rather than its inner composition. The findings help to shine light on how binary systems with similarly-sized stars form and grow from their surrounding disks of dust and gas

Surrounding the two small disks, the researchers found a larger disk — one with a complex, pretzel-like structure of loops — with a total mass equivalent to 80 times that of our neighbourhood gas giant, Jupiter

The team also found that the brighter, but less-massive, of the two smaller disks — the one that is lower down in the ALMA image — is accreting material faster

'We expect this two-level accretion process to drive the dynamics of the binary system during its mass accretion phase,' said Dr Alves.

'While the good agreement of these observations with theory is already very promising, we will need to study more young binary systems in detail to better understand how multiple stars form.'

The pair of baby stars lie in the so-called '[BHB2007] 11 system', the newest addition to a small cluster in the Barnard 59 dark nebula in the larger cloud called the Pipe Nebula, pictured

Astrochemist Felipe Alves of the Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics and colleagues imaged the star system in high resolution using the so-called Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) in Chile

'This is a really important result,' said paper co-author and Professor Paola Caselli, who heads up the Centre of Astrochemical Studies at the Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics.

'We have finally imaged the complex structure of young binary stars with their feeding filaments connecting them to the disk in which they were born.'

'This provides important constraints for current models of star formation.'

The full findings of the study were published in the journal Science.
